<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of connection_add_header:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
connection_add_header (void *cls,
                       const char *key,
                       size_t key_size,
                       const char *value,
                       size_t value_size,
                       enum MHD_ValueKind kind)
{
  struct MHD_Connection *connection = (struct MHD_Connection *) cls;
  if (MHD_NO ==
      MHD_set_connection_value_n (connection,
                                  kind,
                                  key,
                                  key_size,
                                  value,
                                  value_size))
  {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    MHD_DLOG (connection->daemon,
              _ ("Not enough memory in pool to allocate header record!\n"));
#endif
    transmit_error_response_static (connection,
                                    MHD_HTTP_REQUEST_HEADER_FIELDS_TOO_LARGE,
                                    ERR_MSG_REQUEST_TOO_BIG);
    return MHD_NO;
  }
  return MHD_YES;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I found no uses of language/compiler-specific extensions in the provided code fragment. Specifically checked and not present: • No compiler attributes or pragmas like __attribute__((...)) or __declspec(...) • No built-in extensions such as __typeof__, __builtin_*, or __extension__ • No statement-expressions ({ ... }) used as an expression (GCC extension) • No nested functions (GCC extension) • No inline assembly (__asm__, asm) • No zero-length array or other non-standard array constructs • No compiler-specific keywords or storage-class extensions • No use of Microsoft-specific extensions (e.g. __fastcall) or Clang/GCC-only builtins The code uses only standard C constructs: a static function, enum return type and parameter, size_t, a void* cast to a struct pointer, conditional compilation (#ifdef), and macros (e.g. MHD_NO, MHD_set_connection_value_n, _()). These are not compiler language extensions per se. Therefore there are no fragments to report for Rule 1.2.
